section.title: Introduction
section.para: PHP 5.3 is not released at the time this is written, so you won't find it in precompiled for most operating systems. Here we will describe they way to install the most recent release candidate on three operating systems: Debian Linux (Lenny/Etch), MacOS and Windows (XP).

section.title: Installation on Debian Linux
section.para: At the moment there are no official packages for PHP5.3 available. Therefore you will have to adjust your packages sources as follows. You should not do this in your production environment, since you will overwrite your stable and tested PHP 5.2 packages!
Currently you can use the PHP 5.3 RC2 packages provided by dotdeb.org to install PHP 5.3 on Debian Lenny. To do that you have to edit your /etc/apt/sources.list and add these lines:

programlisting.code: # PHP 5.3 packages by dotdeb deb http://php53.dotdeb.org stable all deb-src http://php53.dotdeb.org stable all

section.para: As dotdeb doesn't provide packages for Debian Etch, netlogix backported the Lenny packages to Etch. Packages are available from ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/.
Open /etc/apt/sources.list in your favourite editor and add the following lines to the file:

para.programlisting: # PHP 5.3 packages backported by netlogix deb ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/ etch php deb-src ftp://ftp.hosting.netlogix.de/php5.3/debian/ etch php

section.para:
To install the packages you'll have to do the following:
Update the package cache:
aptitude update
If you already have PHP installed on your system, use the following command to update the installed version to PHP 5.3:
aptitude dist-upgrade
If you do not have PHP installed already, use this to install the necessary packages:
aptitude install apache2 php5 libapache2-mod-php5 php5-sqlite
This will install PHP 5.3, the Apache webserver and the necessary dependencies onto your system. You will be asked a question about installing untrusted packages onto your system. If you want to continue, say "yes".
Optional: If you want to use MySQL as persistence backend you'll also need to install the mysql-pdo driver:
aptitude install php5-mysql

para.bridgehead: Configuring and starting the apache webserver:

section.para: These are some recommended configuration options:

step.para: Adjust the vhost to allow the FLOW3 .htaccess files to configure your environment. The vhost configuration files reside in /etc/apache2/sites-available/:
step.programlisting: <Directory /var/www/> Options Indexes FollowSymLinks MultiViews AllowOverride All # Make sure to set this directive correctly Order allow,deny allow from all # This directive allows us to have apache2's default start page # in /apache2-default/, but still have / go to the right place RedirectMatch ^/$ /apache2-default/ </Directory>

note.para: For a comfortable and secure environment the document root of apache's default webserver instance (or the vhost you are using) should be changed to the "Public" folder of FLOW3. To do that, make sure to change every use of /var/www to /var/www/<your FLOW3 directory>/Public in your vhost configuration.

You should see a page displaying the words "It works!".

note.para: Make sure to remove the RedirectMatch directive (see example above) from your vhost configuration, after you have tested you apache installation. You will need to reload the apache configuration after doing this by issuing /etc/init.d/apache2 reload.

step.para: Test your PHP 5.3 installation by creating a phpinfo.php file in your Apache document root, e.g. by issuing the following command:
Then fire up your browser and go to http://<ip or hostname>/phpinfo.php. You should see a phpinfo page with the correct version number (PHP 5.3RC2) at the top.

section.para: Congratulations, you now have a working PHP 5.3 installation on your debian system, so FLOW3 can be installed.

section.title: Installation on MacOS
section.para: This part explains how to install PHP 5.3 using MacPorts. For this you need to have Xcode installed, you can download and install it from http://developer.apple.com/mac/ (you need a free ADC login for that). After you have Xcode installed, install MacPorts as described on http://www.macports.org/install.php#pkg. You might want to install Porticus from http://porticus.alittledrop.com/ which provides a nice user interface for installing and removing packages with MacPorts. For the next steps we'll assume you use a terminal session, though.

step.para: First of all install PHP 5.3 itself. Along with the port name some variants are specified, those enable additional functionality:

callout.para: This tells MacPorts to update itself and the information about available ports.
Install PHP 5.3 and PEAR including support for Apache 2, MySQL 5, PostgreSQL 8.3, SQLite.

step.para: You can leave out the MySQL and PostgreSQL variants for the start, they are not strictly needed. The whole install can take a long time, as everything will be downloaded and compiled on your machine. An install from scratch can easily take more than one hour.
Now activate the PHP in Apache.cd /opt/local/apache2/modules sudo /opt/local/apache2/bin/apxs -a -e -n "php5" libphp5.so

Now you need to assign the php file extension with the PHP interpreter. For this edit /opt/local/apache2/conf/httpd.conf and add AddType application/x-httpd-php .php inside the <IfModule mime_module> block.
Create a little test script with echo '<?php phpinfo(); ?>' > /opt/local/apache2/htdocs/phpinfo.php
Now you can start Apache with sudo /opt/local/etc/LaunchDaemons/org.macports.apache2/apache2.wrapper start
Call http://localhost/phpinfo.php and check if you have PHP 5.3 up and running.

section.title: Install XAMPP
section.para: These instructions are based on XAMPP (http://www.apachefriends.org/en/xampp.html). They will probably work with several versions of XAMPP. If you have installed XAMPP already, just go on with the next section. If you have another PHP/Apache-Environment, reading the next section will probably also help you a lot to get PHP 5.3 running.

If you don't have installed XAMPP already just download and install the latest XAMPP for Windows as described on their webpage. For these instructions we assume, that you have installed XAMPP in the folder C:\xampp\.

caution.para: These instructions are not meant for live-systems. For those you'll probably be the best administrator yourself

section.title: Download and unzip PHP 5.3
section.para: Download the windows binaries. You need the file php-5.3-win32-ts-VC6-x86-latest.zip (PHP 5.3 - Windows x86 VC6 (thread safe)) from the "windows-binaries-download-page": http://windows.php.net/snapshots/#php-5.3-win32-ts-VC6-x86.
Add the folder C:\xampp\php\php5.3. Extract the content of the ZIP file into this new folder.

section.title: Apache Configuration
section.para: Later you will start another apache process that should have its own configuration and its own log files.
So, what you do first, is

Copy the folder C:\xampp\apache\conf\ to C:\xampp\apache\conf-php5.3\
Create a new folder C:\xampp\apche\logs-php5.3\
Now change the files the new folder conf-php5.3.0\:

listitem.para: Change the port from 80 to 81: Listen 81
Adjust the includes of the configuration files: Search for conf/ and replace it with conf-php5.3/
Adjust the log file directory: Search for logs/ and replace it with logs-php5.3/
Add the configuration for using another PidFile (otherwise you might get some more entries in the error-log) by adding the following line. A good place is below ServerRoot:
Activate the module mod_rewrite by uncommenting the line (this might not be needed anymore in newer versions of XAMPP):LoadModule rewrite_module modules/mod_rewrite.so

section.para: Change the SSL-Port: Listen 4343
Here you tell the apache which .dll-files it should use as PHP-module.

listitem.para:
Add the following lines:#php5.3.0rc2 settings: #Preload the PHP interpreter dll so that apache can find it, even if it's not in the path LoadFile "C:/xampp/php/php5.3/php5ts.dll"
#Load the sapi module for Apache LoadModule php5_module "C:/xampp/php/php5.3/php5apache2_2.dll"
#Specify the directory that the php.ini is stored in PHPIniDir "C:/xampp/php/php5.3"

section.para: Configure the VirtualHosts. Make them reference to the Public folder of your FLOW3 installation.
section.programlisting:
NameVirtualHost *:81
<VirtualHost *:81> DocumentRoot "C:/xampp/htdocs/" ServerName localhost </VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost *:81> DocumentRoot "C:/xampp/htdocs/flow3/Public/" ServerName flow3.local </VirtualHost>

note.para: For other virtual hosts than "localhost" you'll need an additional entry in your hosts-file. Open the file C:\windows\system32\drivers\etc\hosts and add the line 127.0.0.1 flow3.local.

section.title: Problems?
section.para: If you have problems starting the apache, there are two places that mostly help solving them:

listitem.para: Check the error log of the apache. (Did you choose the right log file? You should see the start of the apache in there.)
Have a look at the events in the Windows control panel. Usually you find more detailled information here than in the error log, if the apache crashed.
